text: Pours a clear gold on tap with fluffy white head that leaves moderate lace. Aroma of mild German lager yeasts and bready malt. Taste follows with a touch of caramel and earth. Great to style, solid lager.

On tap at the Heartland Bar & Grill in the Sheraton Madison, WI.. Dispensed to a shaker displaying a clear, golden hue, with a frothy layer of soft white foam, and doily-like cling to the lacing. The nose was lightly perfumed/floral, with pleasant malt & honey sweetness, and just a touch of fruitiness as pit variety. Light to medium bodied, and a lively carbonation, the taste was similar notes, crisp, and nicely sessionable. The bartender was not sure of the style, so due to the light color, fruitiness, lighter body, and modest hop influence, I told him that my impression was that of a Light Hybrid/Blonde. Ill stick with that although there are some similarities between the 2 styles.(Helles & Blonde)

Ar: Rich, clean malt and hints of sulfur; toasted grain, some sugar, and the slightest hints of toffee, bubblegum, and vanilla. Ap: Deep copper-gold, crystal clear; small white head with moderate-low retention, leaving a loose ring of big-bubbled foam and a haze of small bubbles across the top. T: Toasted, full malt profile; rich and grainy, with an upfront sweetness that dries out and gives way to full malt tones through the finish; crackers, bread, and touches of sulfur and butterscotch; low bitterness with a mild herbal character. P: Medium-full body with medium-high carbonation; finish is medium-dry. O: A very solid pale bock; malt richness, the right level of sweetness, and clean fermentation profile; lacks a bit in malt complexity, but thats only a very minor flaw.
Aroma is malt and very "beery". Flavor is malt dominant slightly sweet hint of bitterness and very good carbonation. Excellent body very clean Pleasant finish and super drinkable.

like nectar from the heavens, light and crisp cereal taste with a hint of sweet. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

12 ounce bottle from Woodmans in Beloit, WI, served a little below cellar temp from a NG pils glass. One of those beers Ive had numerous times and just discovered I never rated, so here goes...pours a very clear but very bubbly palest gold, with a large creamy smooth off-white head ...lots of caramel malts in the nose, light herbs (thyme, tarragon), some nice but faint grassy and floral touches...fairly light-bodied, moderately sweet, excellent grain extraction here, the bready malts dominate with the sweetness gradually diminishing and we have a very smooth, lightly sweet, faintly tart and peppery finish. This isnt anything that wows me, but its a hugely drinkable and stylish rendition that I hope returns next time sooner rather than later.
Bottle. Clear gold in color poured with a thin white head that quickly dissipated. The aroma was malty corn with notes of sweet honey. Very clean and drinkable.
Pretty ussualy stuff from new Glarus. Always solid. Very mild simple beer. Not much to say tho
A pleasant tasting lager. Get a bit of caramel and honey. Lively carbonation. Some dryness in the finish.
Honey smell. Taste is honey, a bit of a kolsch type of taste, a bit of bitterness, and a mild honey sweetness in the aftertaste.
Bottle. Pours gold, with a white head. Aroma is grain, honey, and hops. Flavor is honey, hops, grain, and citrus. Medium body. Decent stuff.
Bottled, from shrubber85, golden color with thin foam, sweet honeysuckle aroma, flavor has a nice bock and honey balance , cereal, good finish

Pours a pale straw color. Flavor is light, crisp and extremely refreshing. Extremely drinkable, this is a beer that could be consumed all night long. Overall clean and refreshing. Honey is surprisingly absent for a honey bock.

New Glarus Cabin Fever has a thin-to-medium white head, a deep gold, slightly hazy, bubbly appearance, and very little lacing left behind. The aroma is of mild, subdued malts, and a touch of honey. Taste is of those elements, but the honey and hop bitterness really present themselves in the taste. Mouthfeel is medium, and New Glarus Cabin Fever finishes crisp and refreshing. RJT

Bottle:
Clear gold with a thick white head.
Honey, barley aroma.
Taste is barley malt, honey....
Almost a little smokiness to the honey....a hint of spice...grows sweeter as it warms.....
Pretty good.
Pours a clear yellow with medium head. Very smooth with a good taste of malt and honey. Another good beer from New Glarus.
Not bad for the style, but not my fav. Tons of honey / sulfur flavor, sweet light malt.
bottle shared witrh bunch of pals at club w, party time with jerm in town, clear orange por and crazy smooth stuff...I dig it!

Bottle. Golden with large white head. Aroma of apples, light biscuit, CO2, and floral hops. Medium/light body, moderate honey sweetness, fruit notes (apples, pears), biscuit, light hop bitterness, and dry finish.

Golden brown in color. Clean and refreshing taste and texture. Minimal
Laceing. The honey taste is a bit off.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

pours a clear straw gold with a medium white head. aroma is grass and hay. Taste is sweet, malty. A hint of honey. Sweet finish. Nice lacing. Slightly watery, but very drinkable. Not my style, but good.

Fresh and delicious. Perfect for a snowy Super Bowl Sunday when we actually have cabin fever.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Straight from the bottle. Aromas of caramel, malt, bread, and honey with a hint of hops. Flavor is mildly sweet. Nice beer.

12oz bottle, poured into a snifter. The aroma is initially bready, with a corn muffin touch, combined yeasty, slight damp, egg drop soup funk which fades. The bread and corn remain, although less so, with a faint honey and citrus sweet late. It pours a clear, effervescent gold, topped by a light, fizzy, white head that reduces quick eventually leaving just a small fuzzy island and a touch of lace. The beers taste is a medium-light sweet and light bitter. Its thin, fuzzy, and light. My initial reaction is that its a more polished version of PBR, but not as fuzzy or full, and smoother. The flavors of bread and corn muffin come through first with a honey smoothness and zesty citrus finish containing light spruce notes. Theres a grassy and bread aftertaste akin to aforementioned PBR, but much lighter and more pleasant.

"another via trade w pfoxyjohn...this is a good summer refresher that lets you know lighter fare does not have to be simple or boring. light and crisp, but with a little body and a lot of flavor. nice rich malt & hop balance with a kiss of honey in the finish. aroma is much of the same."

12oz bottle. Appearance is clear pale golden with a small white foam cap that dissipated quickly. Aroma is a bit of bready and caramel malt with a noticeable sweet honey. Taste is rich caramel malt that leads into sweet honey. Hop bitterness is just enough to balance the sweet caramel and honey. Mouthfeel is medium with a low to medium carbonation. Finishes on the malty side with no lingering bitterness. Overall, this has the rich caramel character of a bock, but maybe lacking the hop punch of a true maibock.

Pours amber with a thick, frothy, white head, continuous bubbles rising if various sizes. Blotchy lacing. Nose is typical lager yeast; a bit musty. Taste matches. More on the sweet side, but the hop comes through nicely. Medium body. Lively carbonation. Tasty brew.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

12 ounce bottle poured into a New Glarus Pilsener glass. Pours perfectly translucent gold with a big, rocky white head of foam and lots of bubbles floating through the beer. The aroma has grains, lemon, pear, some bubblegum. The taste is sort of like candied ginger and lemon candy. A little bit bready as well. More sweet than anything else. Light to medium bodied with medium carbonation. Nicely balanced and easy drinking.
A pretty nice, easy drinking bock beer. The honey comes through on the palate nicely. Finishes slightly sweet.

Golden orange, clear, small white head. Sweet molasses nose, some grass. Little bit of citrus. Initial sweetness, some small amount of bitterness. Long finish, relatively effervescent, lighter body. Incredibly well balanced, fantastic beer.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bottle. Pours crystal clear honey colored. Fluffy white head with sticky lacing. Nose is citrus. Sweet taste. Smooth.

Pours a moderate yellow, with aromas of chamomile, lemon, and bread dough. Body is rich, with toffee, wheat cracker, and maybe a hint of honey. I prefer the darker blocks for that richness and malty backbone. This is good but closer to a blonde ale more than anything...
From a bottle in a shaker. Pours bubbly pale amber. Flavor is sweet, wet, and very mild. Most flavor is of honey and sweet smooth grain. Very pleasant lager but a little lacking in depth.
12 oz bottle. Clear yellow brown with a whitish head. Nose is slightly sweet honey and grass. Crisp and clean medium body; a bit sticky. Taste is citrus honey, wheat toast and chestnut.

bottle thanks to CLevar. poured into my trusty snifter. very clear dark gold color. medium sized white head that falls of quickly. nose is initially spicey like a tupelo honey. slightly floral, could be hops or honey. Taste is initially peppery again, but very pleasant. could be german hops. very light malt, slightly crackery, but not really bock-like. this is damn crushable for a 6% beer, but this is no helles bock. just sayin. well, ok, maybe. I like the hops in the beer though.
Bottle. Very smooth and light. The honey flavor is present, but the taste isnt too sweet or syrupy like some honey-flavored beers. Has a touch of bitter flavor, but still very drinkable.
Bottle. Nice clean malty flavor that NG is known for. Very sessionable bock with a honey color and a super smooth finish.

February 14, 2014 via bottle from Churchill. Clear golden pour with nice amount of head that faded relatively quickly. Malty and grainy aroma. Taste was consistent with some spice. Finish was a bit dry with a slightly bitter finish.
Color of a typical lager. Big 2 inch fluffy head. Sweet bready aroma. Kind of a skunky taste. Dont really case for this one.
3/16/2012. From bottle. Pours light orange amber with a white head. Sweet fruity aromas with light malt. Flavors have light spice, honey, caramel and floral notes. Very good for the style.
Pour from a 12 oz bottle. Easy to look at - easy to drink. Just a twinge of honey in the taste and aroma. Lots of bread and a bit of malt in the taste as well.

Bottle, thanks Jeff! Pours clear gold with a fizzy head that slowly fades away. Aroma is sweet cereal grain with some bread and hay. Taste has a very nice honey sweetness that mixes perfectly with cereal and pale malt. Good amount of hops add a nice grassy and spicy taste. Very light bitter finish. Medium body. Mouthfeel is smooth and even a little syrupy. I love a good Heller Bock and this is a very good one.

Bottle: thanks, Jeff! My New Glarus supplier. Slightly muddled, super bright golden body with a small, flimsy white head that quickly sizzles into a mild collar around the edge of the brew. Aroma has notes of sweet honey covered cereal grains, musty & spent hops, pale malts, & perhaps even a little toffee (though I may just be mistaking that for more honey). Taste also carries through with a good amount of honey - sweet but not nearly overboard. You can taste the fresh, bready lager yeast with bright grainy notes, a light dusting of hops that never get bitter, & a pretty dry, clean finish. Lasting reminders of yeast & honeycomb. Its a simple beer, but a pretty nice one at that. Would love to have this in the fridge for simple occasions.
A pleasant beer overall. Aromas are sweet grains. Nice sweet wheat flavors as well. A nice smooth bock.

Pours a nice golden color, white head with decent retention and lacing. Aroma of hay, malt, and honey. Tatse is crisp and light with a decent amount of honey addind sweetness without being over bearing. Good brew from a great brewery.

Hoppy, sweet, hay, honey aroma. 
Tastes the same. Fairly hoppy but with a sweet honey flavor. Bit of a bitter finish. 
Im on the fence with this one, not my favorite New Glarus, but a decent one nonetheless.

Pours clear bright golden with minimal slightly off white head. Aroma is sweet with light straw malt. Crisp light body with a weak finish. Decent beer but definitely like the other new glarus bock better

12 oz. bottle thanks to queenholly. Clear gold without any head. Nose is honey and plenty of breads malts. Flavor is a direct reflection of the honey aroma. Toasted bread with honey with a medium grain body, simple and straightforward Bock. Finish is clean with a sweet honey finish. Did I mention you can find honey in this beer? I enjoyed this and could drink more then one bottle.
Milky orange cream. Nose is rustic with a clean malt profile. The honey hits in the middle and just keeps coming. It really is impressive. Maybe too sweet for me but would be great on a warm day.
Poured yellow with white head decent lace. Sweet honey aroma. Light carb and body tastey honey sweet taste
Pale yellow pour with a nice lager flavor and honey sweetness. Refreshing, but nothing special.

UPDATED: MAR 25, 2017 Bottle. Lemon, cardboard, and barley malt aroma. Golden yellow with giant white head. Mildly sweet lemon, barley malt, and mildly astringent hay flavor.   Okay body.   Tastes like a mediocre lager with light bock characteristics.    Re-rated on 3-25-17 - was hoping I got a bad bottle last time but I didnt change my opinion this time - okay but just middle of the road.

Mildly hazy golden color with a thin white head. Aroma is honey, yeasts, pale malts, caramel, and some mild floral hops. Flavor has a nice honey and caramel sweetness, followed by a solid malty backbone, yeasts and floral hops. Body is light and the carbonation is a bit fizzy but its very crisp. A great Maibock overall
bottle. decent lager, medium to fuller bodied, clean lager with honey induced sweetness. OK
Mild, grassy and delicious. Honied sweetness with a light appearance and a thick lager mouthfeel.
Malty, delicious, round, simple but tasty. Definite honey flavor. Not my style, but very well made.
12oz bottle. Pours a clear golden yellow color with a thin white head. Aroma is of a typical lager with some honey notes. Taste of pale malts, lager yeast, sweetness from the honey, and grassy hops.

Bottle at Drink Beer.. Help People tasting party.  Color is gold with good carbonation and a small head.  Aroma was nonexistent, maybe some malt hiding in there.  It has a lighter medium body and smooth mouth feel.  Flavor is mild sweet malt and a very clean finish.  Overall its light and clean, but just plain and lacking flavor.

Aroma of some sweet malt...not much else.  Light golden in color, high carbonation, white head dissipates quickly.  Sweet, malty, with a pilsner-like essence that fades.  Searching for some distinct honey...but the malt over powers.  Finishes with mild bitterness with some lingering sweet tones.  Not what I expected but a decent session beer for summer.
Bottle. Pour is light golden. Aroma of caramel, honey, and bread. Taste is sweet.

Honey lightly dominates this bock at every turn. Its there ever so gently in the aroma and more noticeably at the finish. Otherwise, this is a a bit more of a traditional bock because the hops have little influence on the taste and the barley is much more noticeable. But now I sound like a beer nerd. Shame on me.

"Cold...very light...a not very intense bitterness on back of tounge... Doesn't really taste like anything..."- Kristina ... But yes a drinkable bock... It has the new glarus classic drinkability i don't think u could honestly dislike too many of there beers... Not mind blowing or amazing just a good clean easy drinker...it would be good By a fire..

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours golden with a finger of slowly dissipating foam.  sweet notes of grape in the aroma.  has a nice little tart apple and grape feel to it that fades to a soft bitter finish.  Not what I expected but pretty good

Thanks to Justin for the bottle. Pours a light gold with a thin white head. Musty, honey, earthy hop aroma. Smooth clean malt and honey in the taste. Really nice. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

UPDATED: DEC 31, 2013 Bright golden with a few streams of bubbles. Fluffy, small white head, lasting. Aroma is sweet, honey, hay, pale malt. Lighter medium body. Sweet, super smooth. Flavor matches aroma. Honey, yeast, hay, pale malt. Finish is lightly fruity with Mild bitterness. Chuggable. Surprised and impressed.
12 ounce bottle.  Pours a clear gold with a nice white head.  Aroma of malt, grain, and grass.  Taste is malt, grain, grass, and a bit of lemon.  Not your typical bock.  Very nice.
Aroma is pale malts, mild grain/honey sweetness and beery.  The flavor is pale malts, a mix of mild sweetness and bitterness and a beery finish.

Poured into a standard pint glass.  Nice 2 finger head, reduces to a ring of carbonation and some residual dextrin on the surface.  Some residual lacing left after the head disappeared.  Once in the glass, crystal clear, and light.  Smells strongly of malt and honey, and some slight grassy hoppy notes.  Tastes strongly of malt, with a perfect bit of honey.  Sweet.  I dont know very much about heller bock, but the dextriny mouthfeel was a pleasant surprise (based purely on the visual).  Solid.

Clear, light gold with foamy white head / Dry, steely nose of grain, resin, and light touch of honey / Medium body, fat, moderately sweet and sticky, with some but not dramatic hop balance, and light bitter finish / Flavors of clover honey, grain, and biscuit / Not an expert on Heller Bocks - this seems to fit the style, while not being special in any particular area.
UPDATED: JAN 12, 2015 Great honey color. Solid malty sweet and honey aroma and taste. A little less subdued than darker bocks but still malty and smooth. The honey adds a nice flavor and presence.

A blonde bock with a thin white head. In aroma, sweet grainy and grassy malt with light talcum, mineral notes, OK. In mouth, a sweet adjunct like bock with corn, grass, so-so. On tap at Istmus Beer and Cheese Fest, Jan 19 2012.
Bottle. Honey in the nose. Honey in the flavor too. Not as strong as your typical bock. But some strength reveals itself as it warms. Understated beer that is nevertheless a quality offering.
Clear straw color. Sweet and sparkling like hard cider. Light as a feather, drinkable as water. A nice change from the usual super-heavy dark winter seasonals.
Not what I was expecting, but still pleasant. Smooth, light honey taste. Easy drinking.

Looking at this beer, you wouldnt think it a bock.  Its bright and clear as a pilsner, with a decent head after a tame pour.  Smells biscuity, with some grass thrown in there too.  Flavor follows, light and grassy and a bit bready - cant taste much honey, though it is there.  Mouthfeel is light, almost like a light lager; good amount of carbonation.  Overall, a decent beer, but definitely not my favorite from them.  Id much rather have a Hometown Blonde if I were going for a lager, as I feel its sweeter, cleaner, and even has a bit more of a honey flavor to it, though that might just be the sweetness talking.

Shared by Thorpe429. Thanks Mike.

The beer is light yellow and transparent with a quarter inch of white head. The aroma consists of grain, bready malt, a touch of lemon, and a hint of alcohol. The flavor is grainy, with a prominent lager malt presence. Fruity aftertaste. Light bodied with moderately low carbonation. Overall, this was ok.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 04-08-2012
Bottle pour while at a Wisconsin wedding.  As others have noted, the honey is not very prominent - Id like it more pronounced
This is by far my favorite beer from New Glarus. Its smooth, good head, beautiful color. The honey isnt overpowering but its just enough to taste and smell it.

12 oz. bottle served in a FFF 15th Anniversary pint glass.

A: Pours a clear golden yellow color with a thin white head forming on the pour. It recedes to a very thin ring and no lace is left down the glass.

S: Nice dried bread crust malts with some lager yeast and light grassy hop profile.

T: More of the whole wheat bread crust malts, pale malts, lagery yeast and a nice light grassy hop profile really round this out with a touch of sweetness.

M: Light bodied. Crisp with a nice carbonation and nicely refreshing.

O: I think this is very solid bock. Nice malt profile balanced with the sweetness and the hops bring really bring together a nice beer.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 04-13-2012
Pours a clear yellow with medium head. Very smooth with a good taste of malt and honey. Simple, understated but quite good.
12 oz bottle crushed with TheRon pours a bright yellow with a lasting, white head.  Lovely sweet, biscuity malts flowing throughout this beer, in flavor and aroma.  A damn good lager.
A nice beer.  Smooth and light but still retains a good medium body.  I wish New Glarus was available in Texas.

Bottle shared by emacgee or durhambeer a while back.  Another fine lager by Dan and the crew.  The sweetness (which can be a bit too much in some Americanized version of heller/maibocks is well controlled, and subtle.  Herbal, grassy hops come out first, some earthy and bready malt, grapes, apple, pear.  Ends with some sweetness which I guess comes from the honey.  Very solid, I hope to get to try this again.

Bottle at home. Poured a glowing orange, almost cider-like color with little-to-no head. Smell is bread, biscuit, light honey, grain, and lager-like corn. Taste is much the same with flavors of sweet corn, grain, honey, and a light bitterness. Thin mouthfeel and soft carbonation. Pretty simple, and better than macros, but really nothing special here.

12 ounce bottle courtesy of Matt Simpson. Thanks, Matt!

Appearance: Pours out a yellow-hued body with good clarity and a foaming, fast evaporating, white head.

Smell: Some pale malts, a tad bready, with some pils malt, notes of lightly sweet-scented honey, herb, and modest underlying yeastiness.

Taste: Pils malts, a bit of graininess, and a medium degree of honeyed sweetness. Herbal hops, though light, as well as is the imparted bitterness. Hint of white grapeskins. Faintly yeasty. Drying, fairy clean finish where, though the overall carbonation is a bit light, theres a fast flash on tingliness as it closes out.

Mouthfeel: Falls somewhere just a bit shy of medium-bodied. Medium-low carbonation.

Overall: Solid little bock.

On tap at Brickhouse BBQ in Madison, WI. Pours a crystal clear, golden body with an off-white, thin head that dissipates quickly and leaves a light lacing. Aroma is lightly sweetened grainy malts with some honey and a light fruitiness. A light breadiness to the malts. Flavor is similar. Lightly sweetened grainy malts with a touch of honey bread. Some light fruits and a touch of sweetness as this finishes clean and slightly dry with a light bitterness. Shorter aftertaste following a light, clean, smooth body and a light carbonation. Overall, a clean and simple heller bock. Grainy with a light honey sweetness and just enough of a bitterness to balance. Not bad.
Nice stuff, both crisp and sweet. The sweetness more from honey than the malt. Serving: Bottle

UPDATED: APR 22, 2012 I like it and would drink it as a session beer when given the chance.  I enjoy the style and this does it justice.

Aroma is bready/malty with some clover that rounds out with honey.

Appearance is a pretty crisp golden clear color that starts off with a bright white head which dissipates pretty quick leaving some light lacing behind.  

When it comes to the taste of this honey bock, its really more of a cereal and bread concoction that has some honey shining through.  More so as you drink it.  Very slight bitterness and probably could use a bit more honey, but its close to being the perfect amount.  Thats just a personal preference for more sweet than bitter.

Its a good beer that is great for drinking lots of in spring to summer weather which isnt what they advertise it as, but for me is more suited to that type of weather.  I like a heartier beer in the fall, winter, early spring. 

Quick re-rate:  I had this when my allergies were bothering me and couldnt get the full flavor.  Second bottle was better and more fragrant and flavorful than the first.  The honey really shined through.  I really like this bock.
A pleasant brew. Smooth beginning and subtle honey sweetness lingers. Tastes good cold.

Big thanks to BeerFMAndy for getting a nice box of New Glarus out to me. Served in a New Glarus tasting glass.

Pours a clear golden color with a nice white head and a touch of lacing on the way down. The nose carries some faint honey and a bit of light bready malt. The flavor hits the light honey notes again with a touch of breadiness through the finish. Some chewiness and a light-medium body. Good carbonation. This was a fairly-solid brew, but I found the honey to be a distraction.

12oz bottle 4/5/12 (Koby)-40° in Lager Glass-Pours a clear golden with a small white head. Aroma of malt and sweetness. Taste of honey, hops, malt, and sweetness. This medium bodied brew is well balanced and goes down easy. Great job.

Pours a clear golden honey color with a thick white head...nice lacing.  Aroma has notable honey and some mild malty notes....yeasty and very faint delicate hoppiness.  Flavor is malty...lightly bready...with a touch of honey sweetness...just enough delicate hops to dry out the finish a bit.  Mouthfeel is medium...faintly bitter and dry in the finish.

12oz bottle. Rating #152. Clear dark yellow pour with a white head. Sweet grainy aroma with the honey coming through pretty boldly. Mild bitterness, more sweet honey with a mild finish. Decent. (2293)
user_location: Redlands, by way of Wisconsin,, California, USA

text: Bottle; Pour is fairly clear golden; a fine bubbled white head that retains well ; some spotty lacing is present ; this one is grains, honey, and noble hops on the nose. It seems a bit over carbonated, and perhaps overly sweet as well. But it is a nice drinker, for sure. Noble hops give way to honey and grain, which gives way to a light bitterness near the finish - revealing a fairly straight forward brew. I think this one was a decent success

Bottle thanks to my beer fairy! Pour has a light honey golden color and a thin covering of white head. Aroma is light on the malt, some grains, German hops, and some sweetness. Mouth feel is light with lower carbonation. flavor has pale malt, German hops again, grains, light bitterness, and faint honey. Very clean beer overall and drinkable.
Sweet taste, light color, not much of an aroma.  Nice rendition of a honey bock.
Mild malt and honey aroma.  Golden amber with off white head...mild lacing.  Malt sweet, mild lemon hop and honey notes.  Great balance, tongue tingler, and full bodied.

Bottle pours gold with a large creamy white head. Aroma is sweet with notes of toasted malt, honey, and grassy hops. Flavor shows slight hints of apple and less honey than was indicated by the aroma. Overall body is light to moderate and the finish is lightly bitter.

Bottle, pours crystal clear gold, one-finger ivory head. Slightly floral, grassy hops on the nose, with a hint of the honey sweetness. Flavor is more fresh grass, just a bit of clove, and honey on the back end. Quaffable, but nothing to get excited about.

From notes.  First reviewed 6/18/2010.  Poured from a 12 oz. bottle into a pilsner glass.

Cabin Fever pours a golden straw color with a 3 cm. white, pillowy head. The head fades rather quickly, leaving just a remnant of its former self. Scattered lace. Some carbonation rising from the bottom of the glass.

Definite honey presence, with soft herbal and grassy notes in the aroma. A touch of bready malt.

The flavor starts with a light, honey sweet light malt. A grassy hay feeling in the middle leads into the herbal hops. A touch of honey helps to round out the flavor in the end.

I could tell from the appearance that this was going to be a little light on the carbonation. Doesnt quite have the crisp feel that I was looking for.

A light, not quite crisp honey lager. It is what it is. Drinkable, but not something I would regularly seek out.
Bottle. Sweet malty aroma. Clear golden with a large, quickly dissipating off white head.  Sweet toasty malt, honey, and a touch of hops which comes off more like spice than bitter. Really nice.

Bottle. Pours clear gold with a tight quick foamy white head that dissipates to a wispy film and tight foamy collar. Aroma comes off with light honey and dark dried fruit and malt all around. Taste is malty and somewhat sweet with the honey and some light spice and pepper. Palate is thin and slick with a chalky dry finish. Another easy drinker that has good taste.

I had this on-tap at local Buffalo Wild Wings in Janesville, Wisconsin in Early 2012.

Pours a clear golden amber color with lots of carbonation. Has a dry, malty scent to it. There are some hints of honey in its taste. Quite smooth and refreshing with a great drinking texture. Some cinnamon and clove spice in the after taste. A nice beer for a cold Wisconsin day.
A good copper color with a nice head that leaves all too soon. Taste is full of malt and has a sweet background of honey. Light but still tasty.

12 oz bottle.  Pours a clear, bright golden with a white head.  Pale malt aroma with apple notes, honey sweetness.  Honeylike flavor as well, lightly toasted pale malts, still a little apple flavor and some earthy hop hints, I think.  Seems pretty well made.

Date: June 04, 2010
Mode: Bottle
Source: Trade
Appearance: clear gold, fine with head with frothy edges
Aroma: sweet honey aroma, touch of sweet cereal, light malt candy sweetness
Flavor: sweet malt flavor, touch of honey sweetness, just enough mild bitterness to add some balance
Aroma: 5/10; Appearance: 6/10; Flavor: 5/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 10/20
Rating: 2.6/5.0Drinkability: 8/10
Score: ** /4

Bottle at Coles. from a Maudite glas, shared with Cole. Pours clear orange; 1-finger white head, lacing is soft to good. Nose is light citrus, slick honey, maple, cream, perfume/spice. Flavours are maple, spice, earthy honey, round, and rich, and slightly nutty. Solid.
Pours clear yellow with a nice thick head. Smells like bread yeast.  Slightly fruity and boozy, very malty great heller bock. pretty nice brew.

12 oz bottle. This one pours a clear golden yellow color and topped by a small head of off white foam that quickly settles to a thin film. Some spots of sticky lace coat the glass. The aroma really shows the honey along with sweet cereal grains, doughy yeast, and some golden raisins. The flavor follows suit with the honey kissed cereal grains, golden raisins, and sweet bread dough yeast as the main components. There is some floral hops that add some needed bitterness on the back end. The palate shows a medium body and quite smooth with moderate carbonation that leads to a sweet honey finish. This is fine example of a heller bock, but just not a style that I care for that much.
Pours gold with thin white head.  Aroma is sweet with honey and malts.  Taste is bready malts, a little citrus and honey.  Palate is average.  The honey overwhelms the beer, so not my favorite.

12oz bottle.  The body is a crystal clear dark golden color.  A moderate head of smooth, off-white foam settles quickly to a thin ring of film.  Traces of sticky, snake-like lacing mark the glass.  Sweet honey really comes through on the nose, suggesting also of glazed puffed cereal, sweet bread yeast, and stewed golden raisins.  Flavors largely follow suit, again showing sweet honey-kissed breakfast cereal, blonde raisins, and sweet baking bread dough yeast.  The difference comes in the hop component, which emerges to show a mild grassy and floral character that is not really prominent in the aroma.  The palate sports a medium-full, silky smooth body, with low to moderate carbonation, though it finishes slightly syrupy and warming with alcohol.  Overall, its a very fine Heller Bock.  Not my favorite style, but this one is a great example.
12 ounce bottle, poured a dark gold with aromas of bread, malt, honey, and a touch of hops and caramel.  Flavor is the same as aroma, with a touch of sweet honey after finish.

bottle sample- pours a light honey colour, excellent clarity and reasonable head. Nose- apples, honey.  Taste- grassy with cooked vegetable in the background. Some sweetness from the malt and honey. Crisp carbonation and slick body.  slightly drying finish.
2/5 in darkness. Smells light malty. Tastes malty and sweet with a similar finish.
355ml bottle shared by jsprime. clear yellow with a whate head. cidery nose. slightly malt forward flavour. clean. not a lot goin on.
Bottle, thanks to tkrjukoff. Golden beer, small white head. Malty aroma, alittle sweetish, bready. Malty, almost sugary flavor.
Bottle (33 cl), courtesy of tkrjukoff. Clear golden, medium white head. Sugary malt aroma with some grassy and herbal hops. Medium bodied with soft carbonation. Semi dry, medium bitterness.

(Bottle) Pours pale golden with a white head. The aroma is slightly malty with bread and honey alongside a light hop hint. Maybe light perfume and grain. The flavor is light sweet, light bitter and tiny acidic. Tones of bread, honey, light grain and light hops. The mouthfeel is clean and soft with a light carbonation. Abrupt finish with a light honey sting. Medium bodied.

Courtesy of northernbrews 
Bottle:  The aroma of light honey and a touch of grass.  It pours a transparent gold with a small white head that quickly fades to a thin ring around the edges of the glass.  The flavor starts with honey and lager yeastiness.  The finish has some light grassiness.  Medium bodied with mild carbonation and a somewhat sodt mouthfeel.  Overall, pretty simple, but still pretty tasty.
Although the honey in this is virtually undetectable, still a damn good beer.
Sweet malty aroma. Pours slightly cloudy golder, thin white head. Sweetness, some grassiness. Some honey in the finish.

12 oz bottle from the back of the beer fridge..part of a mixed pack left behind by nephew Pat...thanks....pours a dark yellow with a brief head....hit by the sweet right away...honey is definitely there / in abundance...let it warm a little and that lessens and lets the barley / hops show thru...definitely a fall / winter beer, which is why I am sure it was tossed into a summer combo pack...but, hey, the AC is cranked up and were losing in Sequence anyway, so kick back and enjoy it...will look it up again next fall...

Bottle. Poured into a pint glass. Huge white bubbly head and thick rings of lacing. Aromas of straw, delicious bready malts, orange and grassy hop notes. Taste is honey, cinnamon apple pie, caramel, german malts, smallest trace of smoke or clove like flavor mixed in. This heller bock had a very smooth but heavy mouthfeel. Great winter warmer but I think it would be hard to drink more than a couple.

Bottle, shared with GT2. Pour is bright gold with a nice white head. Aroma is bready, honey, light hay/grass. Flavor is doughy, lightly sweet, grassy hops. Palate is clean, refreshing. Excellent lager.

355mL thanks to Ughsmash. Pours a clear golden with a larger, pillowy, creme head with decent retention and small lace. Looks great for style. Nose is clover honey and sweet malt with rich German malts and honey wheat bread. Taste is on for style- very doughy/bready, full-bodied, sweet, malt forward. Very good for what it is- simple, sessionable, and exhibiting traditional sweet lager characters minus and soapiness or chemical off-flavors. Clean, fresh palate. Very good. +1 for making an awesome session lager.
Bottle poured a clear yellow with a lasting white head. Aromas of bnread and light honey. Palate was light bodied and smooth with a dry finish. Flavors of bread and light honey with a smooth finish.

Refrigerated bottle obtained through trade from cbfobes poured into a shaker.  Pours light golden with bright white 1" head.  Highly carbonated, good lacing, and silky body.  Taste is grainy malt and some honey.  Good beer.

A clear gold color when poured with minimal head and some leftover lacing.  Aroma was mild, some bread and straw hops but not much.  My first reaction upon tasting was that it was not sweet, which was a good thing, because seeing Honey Bock on the label made me think that it would be.  Again mild tasting, thin body.  Not a bad beer to have in a sample 12 pack.
leaves, medium sweetness, golden, clear, minimal head, white foam, bright, light, good with fish and chicken.  Notes of honey, clover honey added in recipe.

aroma is barley, sweet, light citrus.  Appearance is pilsner color, one finger head, lace.  Low hops and medium malt, high varbonation, sweet malt, and bisquit taste. Palate is heavy mouth feel and was not expecting this color of of a brew to be that hoppy.  Overall, would have again.  A nice semi sweet aftertaste.  This would make for a great winter brew.  I could only drink one of these.  The alcohol content seems a little high with the full mouthfeel.

Lushawn Supplies Bottle.  Big frothy off-white head on this bitch.  Transparent light amber color.  Adjuncty big macro nose, wet grass and hay, sweaty underwear, and the like.  Sticky sweet body but clean enough flavors, but sticky sweet...actually getting some smokiness now, both in the nose and flavor...so sticky sweet and smokey, basically.  Clean flavors though so nothing is insulting my senses, kind of a bit thick for it to be sessionable, but I think I like it better than the Snowshoe I just had.

Hazy gold color with foamy white head; lots of lacing.  Aromatic sweet malt and grainy aroma.  Taste is sweet malt; notes of honey, apple & fresh bread.  Some hops on the finish that balance it nicely.  Smooth palate.  Very good.

"Sooo glad I tried this before it ecscaped for the season. Really delightful. Bright orangeish golden with a creamy white top. Aroma is distinct, sweeter, yet hoppy. Palate has got some noticeable alcohol, but its balanced. Honey, apples and cinnamon with a delightful pie crust like finish. Fantastic :)"

Bottle from Woodmans in Madison. Pours a very pleasant clear gold with a fluffy white head. Nose is mildly sweet, favoring Bready German malts and some nice melanoidin aromatics of round fruit. Very clean yeast profile and a pleasing nobl hop character permeates the palate. Very well balanced and fantastic. No real honey character, but I wouldnt expect that. Fantastic beer.
Pours golden yellow with a big white head.  Aroma of caramel and honey.  Taste is the same with some clove.  Nice.

Bottle lugged back from new glarus by beth- thanks!   pours a clear golden with a huge, cratered offwhite head that leaves some nice lacework on the glass.  aroma of dry, crisp, grassy breads.   flavor of sweet doughy, yet crisp malts and a touch of honey.   very well executed.   tasty.  easy drinkin.  like.  thanks again BETH!

Bottle @ home. Golden orange appearance with a foamy white head. Sweet pale Bock lager nose with some light honey. Light honey, fairly plain pale malty bock flavor. Light bock lager aftertaste. Easy drinking beer but not too special.

You can really taste the honey in the background on this one, not overbearing but very much present. That being the case, I always like beers that fit the styles they shoot for and what more in a honey bock could you ask for that great honey flavor. A nice, smooth, light bock with some complexity but mostly an upfront good tasting beer.

Thanks to Wisconsin John for this brew!! .. Pours a deep yellow, glimmering really- great foam head, and lacing is crazy good .. . Are you challenging my constitutional right to make nude phone calls? .. . aroma of light wood, mr beer juice, and honey .. . pretty simplified, for the novice i guess- but for a bock, i did enjoy it .. . Have you ever heard the expression, When life gives you lemons, make lemonade and then toss it in the face of the person who gave you the lemons until they give you the oranges you asked for in the first place?

Bottle from Festival Foods in La Crosse. Pours a slightly hazy yellow-gold color with a thin off-white head that recedes to an outer ring quickly. Spotty lacing on the glass. Aroma of sweet malt and molasses. Light, clean body with flavors of sweet honey, cereal malt and a bit of spice. The finish is sweet and malty. Slightly above average overall.

Pours dark amber with a nice head.  Notes of malt hit the nose and a deeper sense of the sweet malt shows up on the palate.  You get some very light hops on the end of the taste which also gives a bit of the honey sweetness/depth as well.

The beer pours a clear light gold with a light white head, not much retention or lacing.

The aroma is very light, smells like a beer, with a little sweetness.

The taste is light, like an american lager with a hint of skunkness.

The feel is super light, but decent drinkability.

Bottle from Breeze Thru.  Pours a pale yellow with some fizzy head.  Aroma is bread and honey with some resin.  Taste is some honey, some sweet caramel, some bread.  Quite light.  Finishes mildly sticky.

Bottle courtesy of ughsmash.  Pours copper/gold with a small white head.  Smells of bread, subtle honey, perfumy, light spice.  Tastes of up front honey, some rosey hints, spicy, sweet with some floral notes on the finish.
Bottle shared by Dogbrick. Clear yellow pour with a thick, fluffy white head. Aroma of a lager with a bit of sweetness and noble hops. Flavor starts with honey, then lager yeast and noble hops.

Bottle pours clear gold with medium white head.  Very pleasant aroma of grass, honey, sweet malts.  Sweet taste with grass, bread, malts, honey.  Palate is thin without being watery.  Finish brief with slight hops.  Alcohol not apparent.  Very drinkable, I enjoyed much more than I anticipated.

12 oz bottle.

It pours adeep gold with a fizzy white head that doesnt leave much lacing as it recedes.

It has a classic smell, yes they added honey but the smell is a good helles bock flavor with bready malts, a hint of caramel, some nuttiness and a touch of hops.There is a little bit of fruit in there too.

The flavor is a little bit weaker. The malt is buttery and biscuity and the hops dont really show themselves in the flavor like they should. They add flavor but arent assertive, they do nothing to balance the sweetness. I generally like NG lagers but this one fails in the taste.

Serving type: bottle

Pours amber with white head, aroma has some honey, grass and bread. Taste is nice honey and bad, touch of hops, sweet finish. Nice and balanced.
nice honey flavored bock. Very tasty and the honey taste isnt overpowering.
12 oz bottle.  Pours a clear liquid yellow orange gold with a medium sized off white head.  Aroma of honey, barley and faint hops.  Taste is much the same as the aroma.
Sampled at an ESBLS tasting.  Clear gold pour.  Large bubbles in the head.  This is not a complex beer.  It offers grain, apples, light honey,and sugar.  There is a bit of clover.  A nice beer.

Aroma: nice bready nose, some biscuits, sweet malt, honey.  Hop aroma is present but subdued, a touch of DMS.  Appearance:  crystal clear, straw color, nice billowing head with average retention, subsides to a thin ring of foam, spotty lacing on the glass.  Flavor: sweet malts, light toastiness, bread, honey, some light hop bitterness, no apparent alcohol flavor.  Palate: medium body and carbonation.  Easy drinking bock, so mellow it borders on a session brew; could easily tackle a few of these.

Poured a clear medium gold with a light head which quickly faded to a nice lace.  Aroma was of sweet malts.  The taste was sophisticed - sweet malts with a hint of honey, slight hay, and finished with a light hop flavoring but relatively low bitterness.  Mouthfeel was nice.  Overall a clean smooth brew that is not overwhelming and nice to consume.
user_location: Town of Maple Creek, Wisconsin, USA

text: 12oz Bottle. Thanks Kevin! That is one pale bock. Geez, this beer reminds me of bocks from the northern midwest. They have a characteristic twang to them. Honey maybe, yeast more likely, but some emergent amalgam even more likely. I sometimes have trouble with Hellers. Sometimes they take my beloved pilsner malt and morph it into something sickly and oh-too-sweet. This one doesnt. Keeping pale and crisp, with just enough honey-like character, it stay drinkable, yet engaging. I like the carbonation, the softness, the mineral-like lightness, and the almost Sasparilla-like flavor. God, I miss New Glarus.

12 oz bottle from Casanova Liquors (Hudson, WI). Pours a Nice lightly hazed straw golden hue, well carbonated with a slightly offwhite frothy head that stays ok sized, laces ok. Aromas are pretty bready, crackers and pale malts, touches of slight spice, honey mellow sweetness, touch of clover and faint florals and grass. Clean. Initial is lighter bodied, a touch of sweet breads and honey, faint vanilla, pale malts. Light grassiness, the honey grows on me, tender and light sweetness linger with bread. Very smooth with touches of grass, honey, vanilla, sweet breads and maybe a touch of cornmeal. Tasty and smooth, flows down easily with mellow sweetness, light grassy and clover bitterness, bread and honey. Nice. Mellow. Quality blonde bock, nothing boozy about it

On draft at Harrys.  Pours a golden yellow color with no head.  Aroma is faint, malt.  Medium on the palate with medium carbonation.  Flavor is sweet, a light bit of malt, and bread.  You can tast a touch of the honey.  Very drinkable.

Bottle. Poured into a tall Allagash tulip glass a apple juice colored yellow orange with a 2 finger effervescent head of white. Light white fruit like apple and pear in the nose along with a sweetness like honey. Medium/light mouthfeel. Sweet bready flavor along with some fruit type sweetness. Mimimal hop except at the end and even that is fairly subdued. Nothing too spectacular but decent drinking and refreshing.
One of my favorite all time beers.  Great flavor and malt.  Great color and the rest is to die for.

Bottle. Pours murky rust color with creamy off white head. Nose has soft lightly toasted cereal grains. Flavors are sweet honey, toasted grain, and toffee with slight pear and melon in the finish. Watery feel. Just seems to lack character without any hop presence.

On tap at Old Fashioned in Madison, pours a clear golden with a nice white head and lacing in the glass, aroma is of sweet malt and spices and the flavor is much of the same, straight forward but crisp and delicious, New Glarus does it again.

Pours a beautiful light gold with a large white head. Aroma is a waft of malt. Nice and creamy on the palate, the taste is sweeter than most lagers with a nice malt profile. Slightly sweet on the finish - no hops noted. A good session beer for those long Wisconsin nights. Pairs well with a hot bowl of chili or with a chili dog.
Gold pour with watery white head and lace. Wheat malt and pepper aroma. Honey, light sweet malt, with a dry finish. Medium bodied and fizzy. Nice beer.
Thanks decaturstevo for sharing-12oz bottle-pours a rich white head and yellow color.  Aroma is sweet light malt, 2nd spice hops.  Taste follows.

Notes from Tuesday June 29, 2010
12 oz. bottle from Woodmans Madison

Ar: Some malt and bread, a bit of honey.
Ap: Pours a pale gold with a two finger head that dissipates quickly and leaves little lace.
F: Not terribly complex.  Big doughy bread notes and a bit of sweet honey.
P: Medium body.
O: Im not a huge fan of this style, and I find this beer to be just okay.

Tasted from a bottle purchased at Discount Liquor.  Pours clear golden with a thick white head that leaves an even sheet of lace.  The nose is clear malt with some nuts and a hint of honey sweetness.  The flavor starts with the cereal notes, a hint of almond paste, light green hops, and finishes with a nutty and lightly sweet honey flavor.  The body is medium minus with light carbonation and a medium honey and almond paste finish.

I honestly expected a bit more from this one.  Sad to say but if it was anyone other than NG I would have ratted this higher.  I expected more from Dan and his crew.  Light in color and again less flavor than I expected.  Not much of the honey in there.  I will have to give this one a 2nd attempt, but there is always a good NG beer on the shelf.

Bottle thanks to Eric. Pours a clear golden hue with a large white head. The aroma is sweet honey and pear. The flavor is nice; smooth easygoing malts, sweet honey, fruity- pear comes to mind-, lots of character.

[Bottle] Pours a golden honey color with about an inch worth of dense white head. Aroma of cereal grains, honey and some light lemongrass and herbs. The taste includes lots of sweet honey, biscuits, grains, and grassy hops throughout. Well balanced, with nice prickly carbonation. Very smooth and refined for the style, with a creamy texture to it. This is an extremely well made beer.

Pours a translucent yellow gold with a one finger white head. Nose is fruity and sweet with a bready malt foreground. Flavor is grassy with a caramelly malt backbone and notes of bread and a medium bitterness.
Pour is a bright golden with a large white head.  Aroma is grainy with some sweetness.  Flavor is malty sweet and heavy.  This is ok but nothing great.

bottle-well, this was maybe a bit on the old side but i decided to give it a rating anyways.  golden hue with a small fizzy white head.  sweet malty lightly grassy and pale grains on the nose.  the flavors are dominated by the pale grains, a touch of honey and oxidization.  long grainy finish made this unpleasant.  would like to try a fresh sample someday maybe!

Courtesy of markwise. Pours clear gold with thin off white head. The aroma is sweet slickness, grains, floral hops and honey sweetness. The taste is smooth and sweet and lager-y and grainy. It also has a bit of maltiness and caramel malts in the background into the finish.
Bottle at tasting thanks to decaturstevo. Pours a slightly cloudy yellow with small white head. Nose is honey and clove. Taste is honey and pilsneresque peppercorn.

Bottle thanks to CanIHave4Beers.  Pours light for a bock; dark golden with smallish white head.  Simple flavors... light honey, delicate malts, and a little hoppier than expected.  Simple and delicious, though not one of my favorites from this great brewery.

Bottle shared by durhambeer at the CC gathering - thanks, Bob! Bright golden pour, moderate sediment and a crisp head to it. Soft and sweet nose, not much of a surprise, but also some pleasantly grassy hops blended in. These crisp hops enliven what might otherwise be a by-the-numbers sweetened bock, and is just the kind of thing that NG does to compel such styles. Solid and enjoyable.

This could have easily been a sticky sweet mess, but not in the hands of Dan Carey! It pours a nice bright gold color with a small white fizzy head. The aroma is bready with lager yeast and a touch of honey. The flavor is very good with lots of bread, grapes, lager yeast and some nice honey on the palate. Well balanced and flavorful. Very nice palate, not sticky at all. Very smooth and drinkable. Good bready/grapey aftertaste.

Bottle from a trade with BA CosmoHopHead.  Pours clear gold with a white head.  Nose is honey, bread, sweet white grapes, and a bit of grain.  Flavor is similar with honey, grain, and only very subtle hints of lager yeast.  A masterful lager, one I could enjoy over and over.

This poured a somewhat cloudy yellow color with a normal sized white head. Aroma was of lots of honey, grass, and sweeter malt. Flavor was much the same, with the honey dominating. Nothign special but better than what I was expecting.

Bottle. Clear, golden body with a white, frothy head, mostly diminishing. Light aroma of caramel, honey, hay and toasted grain. Hints of herbs, grass and dough. The flavor is lightly to moderately sweet, lightly bitter and lightly acidic. It finishes lightly sweet, lightly bitter and lightly acidic. Light to medium body, watery texture and lively carbonation. A slight chalkiness built up with every sip. Some beers grow on you the more you drink. This beer got worse. The malty, honey sweetness began tasting like cough syrup. The grainy, biscuity flavors were thick and unenjoyable.

12oz bottled the 1st day of 2010, if Im reading it correctly.  From badbeer Mike.  Thanks.  Clear golden with a small white head, fair retention.  I get some toasted malts, lightly sweet honey, and some lager yeast behind.  Flavor has stronger honey notes, though more of a honey flavor than the sweetness that comes with the honey.  Also a tinge of noble hops.  Finishes with minimal bitterness, lightly sweet.  Moderate prickly carbonation with a light to medium body.  Dunno why they have this as their winter (warmer) beer, as Id rather have this in spring--maybe fall.  Pretty tasty and easy drinking.
user_location: Ocean Beach, San Diego, California, USA

text: Nice beer from a friend at work, picked up on a trip to Fond du Lac.  Pours a clear gold with a nice (though short-lived) white head.  Aroma is decidedly bland, with kind of a plain corn-y malt aroma.  Flavor is far more pleasing though, with nice clean lines of light grain, subtle honey sweetness, and a touch of flowery hops.  Smooth and crisp with a lightly creamy texture, this is a solid brew.
Thanks Andy. Solid beer, nice and fresh. Although there is a bit of banana reminiscent of keystone that i dont find amicable. Honey is light but nice in the finish.
Pours a nice golden color with a healthy head. Not much aroma, and a nice beer flavor. Very light almost like a pils. Very tasty.

12oz bottle.Pours a clear, light straw-gold with a tightly packed, poofy head of suspiciously uniform texture. The head slowly gives way to a small film of bubbles on the top that leaves spares bits of lace on the inside of the glass. Aroma is a little difficult to detect but eventually shows some bready malt and light grassy hops. Flavor is richer than I was prepared for -- I was expecting a standard pilsner-type lager for some reason (partially because the neck label describing the style had fallen off) and didnt realize it was a bock until after I took a sip and went to read the description to see what I had gotten myself into. Anyway, the flavor is big-time rich biscuity and sweet malt with a light, crisp hop bitterness in the background. Palate is medium-thick with a lingering sweet-malt finish. As the name suggests, this is a perfect beer for welcoming the first signs of spring after a long hard Northern Midwest winter.

A great little session beer lightly sweet not quite a "bock" as Ive come to know them but good and easy to drink.
Hints of honey and maybe clove are in the aroma and taste with hints of floral hops and some light malt finishing w/ a bit of lightly toasted grain leaving a lightly bready feeling in my mouth in the aftertaste.  I really enjoyed this.

Oh heck yea - this is a killer heller bock - not overpowering - refreshing, but with just enough body - the clover honey is quite apparent in the nose, and compliments notes of herbal hops, pale malts, some floral character - the flavor is light, clean, crisp - notes of toasted grains - the honey does not make itself known until the finish, but it is very light, and adds a clean sweetness to balance out the crispness of the front end - a very light doughiness at the tail end - subtle and delicious.

Pours a slightly richer than pale golden color with a big fluffy white semi loose head that tightens up and becomes fluffy and beautiful and leaves some good lace on the glass.  The initial aroma reminds me of the boiling beer on the stovetop when you make bratwurst, not a bad smell at all just not one you usually get from beer prior to bringing it to a boil. This gives way to a the dominant aroma which is bready baguette. All of this is accented with some nice but light floral notes. I really like the way this smells, its aromatic but simple, its subtle and clean but has some very definitive characteristics none the less.  The flavor is also very clean and has some nice finesse The thing that catches me right away is that the beer is dry, far more dry than the typical product that advertises honey as a definitive ingredient to the beer. The flavor that the honey imparts is not likely sweetness as the bit of that thats in here seems to be covered pretty well by the malt as opposed to any adjunct. There is some spiciness and richness that reminds me a little bit of good honey, but I will admit that if it didnt say honey on the bottle it is not very likely that I would have picked on on much honey flavor. Which is of course ironic because honey flavor seems to be a very definitive characteristic to many pale/heller/mai bock beers. Beyond this whole honey bit there is a nicely subtle hop zing mainly in the herbal vein. The bready maltiness is just slightly toasty and there is just a slight hint of cereal in there as well.  This is a damn well balanced & wonderfully crafted lager, the likes of which are some of the most exciting beers that New Glarus makes.  The palate is just lightly sharp and the beer is fabulously easy to drink, as evidenced by the fact that as I write this I am finishing the bottle, as opposed to the Barley Wines I have this many notes for after about two oz. I would happily drink pint after pint of this beer.

UPDATED: DEC 28, 2013 Bottle. Thin light gold pour with a fairly quickly dissipating head. Doesnt look all that different than a light macro beer. Nose of mild sweet caramel and bread. Medium-light palate, cereal and honey on taste. Slightly dry finish. Good "hot summer day" beer.
Pale golden, puffy white foam.  Aroma is grainy, honey, toast.  Taste is sweet, honey, grainy, simple.

The Dan Journal #345.  Tasted 5/3/10.  12oz bottle.  Filtered with a golden hue.  Brainy white head.  Aromas of green grassy grains and a touch of honey.  Medium bodied and very smooth.  Mild effervescence and a dry finish.  More of an earthy honey note, not as sweet but still noticeable.  Finishes dry and tart with a lingering subtle bitterness.  Im not too sure if thats from the honey or the faint hops.  Either way it really rounds out the palate.  Easy and sessionable with a full rounder palate.

A nice solid drinker.  Standard nose.  Light appearance and nice taste.  Im not so sure what to add on this one.  Poured a nice full head which went away.  Very balanced and nice although light on flavor.

Cloudy orange, thin white head. Smells beery. You know what I mean - it smells like beer. Flavor is surprisingly crisp, with a touch of honey. Some caramel and toast, as well. Not bad, crisp and easy to drink. Thanks to lithy for this one!

Bottle. Pours gold with a thin white head. Aroma is sweet with a strong honey note and a caramel note. Flavor is quite sweet as well with honey, cereal and caramel notes. Surprisingly thick on the tongue.

Clear golden amber with a thin white head with some foamy lacing.  Aroma of honey, corn flakes, light toffee, toasted malt and stale socks.  Taste of mild honey, grains, toasted malt, light fruit and more corn. Pass.

12 oz. bottle courtesy of a trade with Ughsmash.  Pours a clear gold with a thin-moderate linen white head that lasted through the first quarter of the glass and left bits of lace.  Mild aroma of malt with a few notes of grassy hops in the nose as well.  The flavor is malt with just a bit of honey sweetness and some very mild grassy hops at the finish.  Very easy going down.  This is a nice enjoyable bock beer.

Yellow pour, with a frothy white head.  This one has a smooth macro-brew type of body, with a slightly sweet finish.  Along with the finish come a flat texture, which really hurts the score for this one.
Much lighter than I expected for a bock. Not bad but I was definitely expecting more. Couldnt taste much honey. Seemed pretty regular.

Draft at the brewery.  Pours a clear gold color with a finger-thick white head and visible carbonation.  Aroma of sweet malts, honey, straw, grains, and the faintest of hops.  Flavor is also big on honey and sweet malts, with some grains and hops, sugar and grass.  Light-bodied, with a good amount of carbonation and a slightly sticky mouthfeel.  Dry and sweet.  Not bad, but certainly overshadowed by a few other things I tried at the brewery.

Im drinking this a little too late, as the last of the winters snow has melted. While I have been anxiously awaiting the summer for months, this beer temporarily brings me back to the nostalgia of a below 0 winter day. Snow, mountains, a roaring fire, and bottles of Cabin Fever.

12oz bottle, courtesy of joet. Thanks, Joe!! Pours a very bright, effervescent, medium-golden color; very bright appearance; fine-bubbled white head with good retention and attractive lacing; great-looking pour. This is lovely. Perfectly balanced aroma, showing lively citrus, crisp malty notes of honey and cereal, hay, hints of grass, and delicate noble hop character; the honey presence is quiet, well-integrated, and nothing close to cloying. Medium or medium-light body: creamy texture in the mouth, with moderate amounts of carbonation; the honey notes ring clearly upfront, along with mineral and spicy bitterness, creamy cereal and hay-like malt presence, everything just beautifully put together and cleanly presented: gorgeous heller bock, and shows much of the charisma, balance, and liveliness that something like the Sierra Nevada Glissade doesnt quite reach; damn, this is tasty stuff. Medium finish, showing lingering honey, mineral and spicy bitterness, and just a nice reminder of the clover honey and noble hops that define this beer; clean, hugely drinkable, nicely balanced ending.

Bottle. Pour was light to medium golden with a nice white head. Aroma was crisp with honey, light malt, and some bread characters. Flavors were well blended with a small toasted character, slightly sweet malt background, and a medium to low character of sweet honey. Good brew.

Appearance: Pours a light yellow gold wit a thin white head. The body is clear with visible rising carbonation.

Aroma: Spicy hops, dry malt and honey suckle.

Taste: Spicy hops, sweetness (somewhere between sweet corn and honey) and some crusty bread notes.

Mouthfeel: Full bodied with medium carbonation.

Overall: Great, smooth, slightly sweet lager.  Reminds me a bit of Full Sail LTD 02 Lager, which is one of my seasonal favorites.

Has a good, balanced aroma.  Pours clear, sparkling with an even white head. First taste was of a pale lager.  But then it finishes with a complex, citrus, honey flavor that is long lasting. Nice blend of hops that adds interest to this beer.  Another good beer from New Glarus!  Worth buying again.

Bottle. Poured a clear golden color. The head was three fingers high with decent retention. Some lace was left behind on the glass at the end. Smelled of honey-touched cereal grain and subdued grass. There was also a whiff of yeasty bread dough. Light to medium bodied and delicately sweet without any significant bitterness. Carbonation was low to moderate creating a relatively smooth mouth feel. Tasted of biscuit with a dram of honey.

On tap at the brewery.  Nice dark golden pour wit ha thin white head.  Aroma was sweet malt, a little caramel with a touch of something floral.  Favor was really mild with a good sweet kick and a super smooth mouthfeel.  Really easy drinking pleasant Bock.

12 oz bottle

Thanks to noncaloric for sending a pair of these in a trade. I almost drank both in a single night because this is one of the lightest easiest drinking bocks I have tried that still has enough flavor to set it apart. It still falls near the bottom of the spectrum for New Glarus but that has more to do with their upper range and the style. If I could still buy New Glarus locally there would probably be a six pack in the fridge as I type this.

Aroma / Appearance - Golden yellow with strong carbonation the body sparkles with life. Delicate, the foamy head bobs like an ice floe above the liquid supporting it. Honey drizzled over toasted white bread and a mild sweetness gives this some flavor. It is somewhat weak; however it was just enough to meet my expectations.

Flavor / Palate - Honey, dry white toast, and a trace amount of sugary glazing put this a step or two above Totally Naked. Still fairly bland the finish is about what you would expect. The only unusual thing is the mouthfeel which is heavier than anticipated for what is a lightweight beer. New Glarus hasnt exactly hit a home run but this is just what you would expect for something that appeals to the masses.

12oz bottle via trade thanks to oach on BA.  The appearance is absolutely brilliant.  Crystal clear golden with a creamy white head that lasts.  Excellent thick lacing.  Aroma is pretty standard for a heller bock, with pale malt and mildly sweet honey.  Flavor is decent, mainly pale malt and honey, along with considerable graininess.  Some mild hop presence.  Dry and crisp on the palate with medium body for the style.  Overall this falls in the "good for the style" category.  Very drinkable.  I respect New Glarus for brewing good examples of subtle styles rather than doing just high ABV -bal aged stuff.

Bottle.  Poured a clear gold, with a large white head, some lace.  Aroma of honey sweetness, toasted malt, some light spice.  Taste is similar, with some nice sweetness in the finish.  Body is medium with average carbonation.

12oz bottle at the DC local tasting.  Pours a totally clear, straw yellow with a frothy white head.  Aroma is standard lager, pale malts, sweet, a little grassy.  Flavor is sweet, grassy, a little light honey sweetness... but where is the honey?  Finish is crisp.  If you advertise honey, you better produce it.

Pours a clear, slightly peachy gold with a 1 finger creamy white head that recedes to a nice thick skim after a few minutes and leaves a few spots of lacing. Aroma is grass, toasted grain, crusty white bread, dusty dried grass, mineral notes and nice floral hops. Flavor is sweet cereal grains, dry grass, hay, floral honey notes, a little corn, lots of crusty white bread, some nice, crisp mineral notes and a light hop bite at the finish. Palate is on the light side of medium bodied and pretty heavily carbonated (a little too heavily, but it fits the beer pretty well) and has a slightly oily entry, leading to a somewhat dry finish.

12oz bottle, thanks nimbleprop.  medium white head atop clear straw body.  Aroma is moderately sweet, caramel, honey, some bread.  Taste is moderately sweet, caramel, honey, light bread, earthy.  Light-medium body, light stickiness.
Nice clean yeast; lightly sweet honey malt; just a touch of bitterness from the hops on the finish. Rather nice.

Pours to a clean golden body with a tall white head thats foamy and frothy.  Nice lacing.  Looks great!  Looks like a "beer" should.  The beer aroma is sweet honey and reminds me of an Oktoberfest.  Has that autumn flavor.  Perhaps thats all the honey?  Clover leaves and flowers.  Dry bock even with all the honey.  The palate is really simple to drink.  Very clean body.

Pours a lovely pale golden yellow, with medium-sized white creamy head. Flavor is complex, with some sweetness, some grassy flavors, and a touch of hop bitterness. This would make a very nice summertime beer--late winter isnt the right time for it.

Clear yellow with a medium white head.  Aroma is a bit grainy with some honey.  Flavor is much like a normal lager, honey barely peeks out on the tongue. Creamier than most macro lagers and quite refreshing.  Would love to drink this on a hot summer day.

Thanks to Exiled for sharing this bottle.

The beer pours macro yellow with a white head. The aroma is corny with some wheat. The flavor is corn, wheat, some fruit and honey. Not very much hop character in the beer. Medium mouthfeel and medium carbonation. Not bad but nothing special.

Pours golden and clear with a small white head aromas are off pale malts,honey,and hops flavors of the same with not a lot of the honey coming thourgh easy drinking,with a smooth,creamy and slightly sweet one of their brewed for the masses beers
Daughter recommended this brew, but it didnt meet expectation.  It was OK, but there are alot of beers Id rather drink in the middle of a WI winter.

Dark yellow color with a large head.  Floral and spicy hop aroma with strong grains.  Flavor is very strong on the raw grains.  Light corn and a floral hop bitterness.  It seems more like a well made pale lager than a heller bock, though heller bock is technically a pale lager...
hay, citrus, basement aromas, bubblegum, golden, sparkling, white foam, medium sweetness, lightly bitter, lightly sour, light body, thin feel, lively,

Picked up a single 12-oz bottle at Flanagans in Appleton, Wisconsin. Pours a clear golden amber colored brew with a slow dissipating -off-white head. Aroma of golden grain malt, floral hops, light honey, and some mild vanilla. Taste is medium bodied, slightly sweet with flavors of golden grain malt, honey and floral hops. Finish is semi-sweet, some mild short lived bitterness and then a honey golden grain malt aftertaste that slowly disappears. Actually, a nice session heller bock for the winters.
Golden color with a thin but foamy white head. Aroma of honey and hops. Anitialy sweet taste of honey with a light malty body and high carbonation. Not bad but overall dominated by the honey.

Pours a clear red-gold with a thin white head.  Aroma has hints of malt sweetness.  Subtle malt flavor, some honey.  Light-medium bodied, no hop bitterness.  Just ok, needs a little more flavor and body.

12 ounce bottle courtesy of madvike. Thanks! Pours a clear pale golden color with a thin white creamy head. Good head retention and lacing. Aroma of grassy hops and pale malts with a sweet honeyish finish. The taste is sweet and dominated by the honey, with some toasted malt notes, caramel and a grassy hop finish. Medium bodied and smooth. Good beer, highly drinkable.

Clear yellow gold color with a good sized foamy head.  Grain and yeast combine for a faintly metallic aroma.  Flavor is Grain and light grassy hops with a bit of malt in the back.  Light and a bit watery on the palate.  Not quite what I expected from a heller but decent enough.

New Glarus: the only brewery that could make me excited about a pale bock.  Golden pour with a white head that settles into a film.  Malty sweet aroma with light hints of honey, a bit of clove and other spices.  Flavor is somewhat sweet, light honey notes intertwined throughout and a light bitterness.  Medium bodied, nice and lively on the palate.  Finishes clean and nice.

aroma is clean pilsner malts and fleeting honey note that at times combines to dog urine.  honey fades and palate cleans up leaving pale, clean grain and strong nearly sharp floral note.  ultra sharp pour, translucent straw with low cab and absolutely zero lacing.

Certainly not like a bock, but a good beer nonetheless.  A yellow lager with a little haze.  Considerable yeast, malt, and a little honey, but it makes me think of more of a helles or even kolsch than a bock.  Like most New Glarus lagers, this is exceptionally drinkable.

12 oz bottle.  Pours clear and golden, very light lager-esque.  Lots of bubbles rising in the glass.  First sniff from the bottle reminds of Miller Lite.  Aroma from the glass fairly similar, but with slight honey and grassy notes.  Flavor sweet and malty up front with honey pretty prominent throughout.  Finishes with crisp hops and some grass.  Tiny amount of hop bitterness lingers.  Not horribly complex, but done well.

Bottle. Pours a clear bright yellow with lively carbonation. Visually it could be mistaken with a  macro. Flavor is light and sweet, golden barley and hints of honey. Light bodied and smooth with floral and Euro hop notes. Slightly sweet in the finish. This beer is amazing! Could drink this often.

Pours a clear honey color with very thin white head. Aroma is very mild, just a blend of barley and hops. Flavor is at first the standard earthy barley/hops and after wards the honey flavors hits the tongue. Its almost that one the honey flavor registers the beer seems as if syrupy on the palate, however that is not the case. Body is light yet creamy with a fair amount of carbonation.

Bottle.  Clear lager yellow pour, little carbonation and a pleasant honey and malt aroma.  Flavor wasnt to complex, but decent amount of honey and light hops and finished dry, sweet and well balanced.  Very good.

Thanks for the bottle bro!  Pours a clear straw color with bubbly white head.  Aroma is of light honey, caramel malt, light floral hops and light ripe fruit.  Taste is of sweet malt, honey sweetness, toasted grain and light fruit.  Has a slight tang in the mouthfeel, but it fits the beer well.  Good offering from Dan and company.

UPDATED: FEB 20, 2012 (bottle) Pours a perfectly clear light golden color with a dense, medium white head and a bit of lacing.  Aroma isnt particularly strong, some light floral honey, significant lager yeast, must, breakfast cereal, and some dough.  Light kicks of hops.  The flavor is also not particularly strong or complex, but its really well put together, with a restrained underlying sweetness that begins in the mid until ending quite toasty and faintly bitter on the finish.  The sweetness is reminiscent of honey butter spread over toast, and exhaling after drinking accentuates this effect.  Mouthfeel is medium, with fairly lively carbonation.  This is simple, restrained, and highly sessionable.
(re-rate)  Ive craved this beer from time to time since having it last, and I believe this batch is even better than last years.  Just an excellent lager.

Now seems to be just called Honey Bock with Cabin Fever found around the picture on the label.  Pours a crisp yellow-gold color with a medium creamy and soapy white head which fades rather quickly.  Aroma is roasted grains, honey, and light citrus.  Taste is thicker than a Pilsner but has similar carbonation, and the palate has a bit of citrus and lots of toasted grains.  Drinkable as all hell.

12oz bottle.  Hyper-filtered orange yellow beneath a thin, soapy head.  Sweet, fresh honey-malt aroma with a gentle bock touch.  Smooth on the palate, medium bodied.  The honey just works perfectly with this one, smoothing the beer out.  Certainly still displays some fruity bock yeast tones as well.  Excellent, with a clean, freshness that NG really excels at.  Mild hop balance, just enough to work with the carbonation.

Very light,bright hue, getting mostly grain in aromaway deep down there is some sweet malt,probaly the honey influence, taste is sweet on the tongue, again from the honey, liked you poured honey on bread crust,very light in body, actually enjoyable to drink,like a stepped down Helles bock

Pale gold, dense white head with a sticky lacing. Aroma of fresh bread dough with a floral hop edge to it. Flavor-wise, floral and fresh-mown grass hops aromatics are at the front, which harmonize with the alcohol content for a very zesty flavor. The bready malts found on the nose develop more towards the finish. Warming, lively palate.
hints of honey on the nose.  not too overpowering.  my first thought after tasting this beer...lager!  sweet.  well balanced.

Brand-spankin new off the shelf.  Pours straw-colored with a creamy white head that dissipates quickly.  Very clear.  Not much of a nose - light malts with a little sweetness.  Definately a decent malty taste up front with a decent background honey flavor.  Showcases this flavor much better than another Wisconsin honey beer that shall remain unnamed.  Crisp with low to medium body.  Mild hop flavor on the finish.  Very good and refreshing, just not anything outlandish.

Bottled.  Poured crystal-clear lighter golden with a short cap of white head.  The aroma picked up sweet hay, biscuits, and honey with a deeper earthy and black peppery character.. the honey really rounds it off nicely.  The flavor had a tangy, yeasty opening impression with sweet honey rolling onto the middle.. pale malts and something corn-like down there too.. mild bitterness in the form of earth and faint fruit.. finished sweet with more honey and dusty yeast.  Light-medium bodied with moderate-plus carbonation that worked well here.. fairly crisp feel.. very easy drinkin.

Bottle picked up from the brewery on a Golden Ale run - Pours a nice light amber with a massive frothy cream head. Nose is all malt and barley, real fresh and pungent. Theres almost a melon frutiness thats intermingling with some faint hops to make some light sourness. Was a bit sweet initially, but that faded pretty quick. Oh man...the honey is right there on the first sip, and then transitions into the barley with apple and grape notes. Just a hint of herbal hops on the finish. Sweet, but not overbearing by any means, and with some nice boozy notes that warm rather than bite. The carbonation is dialed up too much, but the light body makes this really easy to drink. This one grew on me as I got through the bottle.

Seems to me the first time NG made Cabin Fever it was a belgian style ale. Thats ok, Ill take another bock. Clear light golden color with a moderate off-white head. Clean aromas, with honey, pale malt, and hint of alcohol (akin to a malt liquor). Pure malt sweetness from the first touch of the lips. LIght honey and hints of alcohol. Light floral hops. Thicker feel with just enough zip to help it across the palate. Strong malt goodness.
